#Text=III .
#Text=THE AURICULAR TALENT OF THE HON .
#Text=SAMUEL BUDD
#Text=Behind us came the Hon. Samuel Budd .

#Text=Just when the sun was slitting the east with a long streak of fire , the Hon. Samuel was , with the jocund day , standing tiptoe in his stirrups on the misty mountain top and peering into the ravine down which we had slid the night before , and he grumbled no little when he saw that he , too , must get off his horse and slide down .
#Text=The Hon. Samuel was ambitious , Southern , and a lawyer .
#Text=Without saying , it goes that he was also a politician .

#Text=He was not a native of the mountains , but he had cast his fortunes in the highlands , and he was taking the first step that he hoped would , before many years , land him in the National Capitol .
#Text=He really knew little about the mountaineers , even now , and he had never been among his constituents on Devil 's Fork , where he was bound now .
#Text=The campaign had so far been full of humor and full of trials -- not the least of which sprang from the fact that it was sorghum time .
#Text=Everybody through the mountains was making sorghum , and every mountain child was eating molasses .

#Text=Now , as the world knows , the straightest way to the heart of the honest voter is through the women of the land , and the straightest way to the heart of the women is through the children of the land ; and one method of winning both , with rural politicians , is to kiss the babies wide and far .

#Text=So as each infant , at sorghum time , has a circle of green-brown stickiness about his chubby lips , and as the Hon. Sam was averse to “ long sweetenin ' ” even in his coffee , this particular political device just now was no small trial to the Hon. Samuel Budd .
#Text=But in the language of one of his firmest supporters Uncle Tommie Hendricks :
#Text=“ The Hon. Sam done his duty , and he done it damn well . ”

#Text=The issue at stake was the site of the new Court-House -- two localities claiming the right undisputed , because they were the only two places in the county where there was enough level land for the Court-House to stand on .
#Text=Let no man think this a trivial issue .

#Text=There had been a similar one over on the Virginia side once , and the opposing factions agreed to decide the question by the ancient wager of battle , fist and skull -- two hundred men on each side -- and the women of the county with difficulty prevented the fight .

#Text=Just now , Mr. Budd was on his way to “ The Pocket” -- the voting place of one faction -- where he had never been , where the hostility against him was most bitter , and , that day , he knew he was “ up against ” Waterloo , the crossing of the Rubicon , holding the pass at Thermopylae , or any other historical crisis in the history of man .
#Text=I was saddling the mules when the cackling of geese in the creek announced the coming of the Hon. Samuel Budd , coming with his chin on his breast-deep in thought .
#Text=Still his eyes beamed cheerily , he lifted his slouched hat gallantly to the Blight and the little sister , and he would wait for us to jog along with him .
#Text=I told him of our troubles , meanwhile .
#Text=The Wild Dog had restored our mules and the Hon. Sam beamed :
#Text=“ He 's a wonder -- where is he ? ”
#Text=“ He never waited -- even for thanks . ”
#Text=Again the Hon. Sam beamed :
#Text=“ Ah !
#Text=just like him .
#Text=He 's gone ahead to help me . ”
#Text=“ Well , how did he happen to be here ? ” I asked .
#Text=“ He 's everywhere , ” said the Hon. Sam .
#Text=“ How did he know the mules were ours ? ”
#Text=“ Easy .
#Text=That boy knows everything . ”
#Text=“ Well , why did he bring them back and then leave so mysteriously ? ”
#Text=The Hon. Sam silently pointed a finger at the laughing Blight ahead , and I looked incredulous .
#Text=“ Just the same , that 's another reason I told you to warn Marston .
#Text=He 's already got it in his head that Marston is his rival . ”
#Text=“ Pshaw ! ” I said -- for it was too ridiculous .
#Text=“ All right , ” said the Hon. Sam placidly .
#Text=“ Then why does n't he want to see her ? ”
#Text=“ How do you know he ai n't watchin ' her now , for all we know ?
#Text=Mark me , ” he added , “ you wo n't see him at the speakin ' , but I 'll bet fruit cake agin gingerbread he 'll be somewhere around . ”
#Text=So we went on , the two girls leading the way and the Hon. Sam now telling his political troubles to me .
#Text=Half a mile down the road , a solitary horseman stood waiting , and Mr. Budd gave a low whistle .
#Text=“ One o ' my rivals , ” he said , from the corner of his mouth .
#Text=“ Mornin ' , ” said the horseman ; “ lemme see you a minute . ”
#Text=He made a movement to draw aside , but the Hon. Samuel made a counter-gesture of dissent .
#Text=“ This gentleman is a friend of mine , ” he said firmly , but with great courtesy , “ and he can hear what you have to say to me . ”
#Text=The mountaineer rubbed one huge hand over his stubbly chin , threw one of his long legs over the pommel of his saddle , and dangled a heavy cowhide shoe to and fro .
#Text=“ Would you mind tellin ' me whut pay a member of the House of Legislatur ' gits a day ? ”
#Text=The Hon. Sam looked surprised .
#Text=“ I think about two dollars and a half . ”
